Bomb Suspect Warned U.S. Nine months before the attack on the American Embassy in Kenya, United States intelligence officials received a detailed warning that Islamic radicals were plotting to blow up the building, according to Kenyan and American officials. The warning came from an Egyptian man, Mustafa Mahmoud Said Ahmed, who is now in jail in Tanzania, charged with bombing the embassy there. A1

Agency Shuffling in Washington Two independent foreign affairs agencies, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the United States Information Agency, were abolished this week by a stroke of President Clinton's pen, A third, the United States Agency for International Development, will have its independence sharply curtailed under a reorganization plan for the State Department that was championed by Republican leaders in Congress. A11

Meeting at U.N. on Iraq Missiles Experts on chemical and biological weapons began a meeting at the United Nations to examine whether Iraq had loaded deadly nerve gas on some of its missiles. The scientists' meeting took place as the United Nations planned a meeting for today on questions from Iraq about what it could expect if it were to reopen the country to arms inspectors. A5

Furor Over Religion in India Religion and politics collided over a proposal to make the study of sacred Hindu texts compulsory for all children in India, a vast country of many faiths. The Government, which is led by Hindu nationalists, circulated the proposal to state education ministers before convening an official conference. A result was a whirlwind of protest from opposition political parties and even some of the administration's allies. A9

Bishop's Death Still a Mystery Forensic teams from three countries have come to much different conclusions in the unsolved slaying nearly six months ago of Juan Gerardi, a Roman Catholic Bishop and human rights advocate in Guatemala. A3

Nervousness on Primakov Plans Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia has been leading one of the biggest nations on earth through the worst fiscal crisis for six weeks, but nobody outside the Kremlin knows what he is doing. Whether this is by design or accident, or good or bad, is open to dispute. But it is indisputably making economists, financiers and politicians nervous. A10

NATIONAL A14-21

Taking Guns Into Mexico Is a Costly Mistake for 78 United States and Mexican officials both say they are unsure why Mexican prosecutors seem to have stepped up the prosecutions of American citizens who enter Mexico with firearms; there are 78 such Americans behind bars in Mexico. A14

And Now, Monkey Think? Two rhesus monkeys whose cognitive skills are being studied at Columbia University can arrange things in serial order, an ability that is presumably part of the human heritage, too, and that may be the origin of the ability to handle syntax, the rules for arranging words in meaningful order in a sentence. A16
Huge Fisher-Price Recall Fisher-Price is recalling up to 10 million battery-powered Power Wheels cars and trucks because they can catch fire or fail to stop. A16
New Rules for Wiretapping The F.C.C. issued proposed rules intended to settle a dispute over high-tech wiretapping between the F.B.I. and the telecommunications industry and privacy advocates. A19

Diesel Settlement Challenged Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York took preliminary steps to challenge a huge national settlement between Federal authorities and diesel truck engine manufacturers, saying it would do too little to prevent smog and acid rain in the state. A16

A Finding of Arson in Colorado Federal arson experts in Colorado have concluded that the recent fires atop Vail mountain were almost certainly set deliberately, law enforcement officials said. That means the case will be investigated as an act of environmental terrorism. A18
Clinton Repents to His Church President Clinton has sent a letter to the members of his home church in Little Rock, Ark., expressing repentance and asking the Baptist congregation's forgiveness. A19
NEW YORK/REGION B1-14

New Jersey to Abandon Car Pool Lane Experiment Governor Whitman, bowing to pressure from drivers, said she would end New Jersey's experiment with car pool lanes on two heavily traveled highways and that the state would not repay the millions of Federal dollars used to build them. B1
Protest Against Brutality More than 1,000 protesters, hemmed in by a throng of police officers on foot and on scooters, marched down Broadway to protest police brutality. No arrests were reported. B3
Council Enacts Campaign Law The City Council overrode a mayoral veto and revamped the city's campaign finance system to discourage candidates from accepting donations from corporations. B3

Pitcher's Family Leaving Cuba Cuba gave the mother, children and ex-wife of the Yankees pitcher Orlando Hernandez permission to come to the United States, and they are expected to attend the Yankees' homecoming parade this morning. D1

Finding in Sprinter's Death The Olympic sprint champion Florence Griffith Joyner died of suffocation after suffering a seizure while she slept, medical authorities in Southern California said. The seizure, they said, was caused by a congenital abnormality of blood vessels in her brain. D1
A Union of N.B.A. Players More than 200 locked-out N.B.A. players gathered in Las Vegas, Nev., for a show of unity. D1

BUSINESS DAY C1-22, 24 Bankers Trust Losses Bankers Trust reported a quarterly loss of $488 million, much worse than expected, and announced a cost-cutting plan that could lead to layoffs. The results reflected the impact of Russia's default on some debts and other foreign upheavals. C1

U.S. Operation Hurts Nomura Nomura Securities, Japan's largest brokerage, reported a $1.76 billion loss for its fiscal first half and provided an emergency infusion of funds to rescue its hemorrhaging American operation, which caused most of the losses at the parent company. C1

An Accusation of Complicity A Microsoft lawyer at the company's antitrust trial portrayed Netscape as a willing participant in deal-making that culminated in a 1995 meeting at which the Government and Netscape say Microsoft illegally offered to divide the market. C1

Stocks Maintain Momentum Blue-chip stocks staged a late comeback and pushed the Dow to a seventh straight gain, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq market continued a two-week advance, rising to nearly 20 percent above its low on Oct. 8. C6
